title: _.random IEEE 754 comments
body:
https://github.com/lodash/lodash/issues/1540

I don't know why the PR has changes that you made some days ago on your main. The only change I made was the comments after a fresh clone?

title: _.throttle synchronous invocation
body:
I don't think there's anything in the documentation that would indicate either way, but will `_.throttle()` actually invoke its callback **synchronously** if its wait period has already passed?

If so, this is rather surprising when you think of throttling as a fundamentally asynchronous operation, and has the potential to cause subtle code path changes (sync vs. async) when you manage to block your main thread just long enough to surpass the wait period.

Asking for a friend.

title: range: Produce more exact fractional results
body:
Previously, `range` performed na√Øve summation, accumulating a larger and larger error on each iteration. This produced some annoying inexact values in the resulting array, but it also led to the final values of the array possibly being off by a significant amount.

This new method checks for fractional `step` values and attempts to generate the most exact results possible.

Fixes #1539.

/cc @zachhale @jdalton @jridgewell 

NOTE for anyone who didn't read the whole #1539 thread: the method used here provides _significantly_ better results than attempting error compensation using Kahan's method or any others attempted (unless I just implemented error compensation incorrectly several times).

title: perf.js: changed references to `{lodash,_}`.`include` to `includes`
body:
```
lodash/perf $ ack '_\.include'
perf.js
1087:    Benchmark.Suite('`_.includes` searching an array')
1092:        _.include(numbers, limit - 1)'
1097:    Benchmark.Suite('`_.includes` searching an object')
1102:        _.include(object, limit - 1)'
1106:  if (lodash.include('ab', 'ab') && _.include('ab', 'ab')) {
1108:      Benchmark.Suite('`_.includes` searching a string')
1113:          _.include(strNumbers, "," + (limit - 1))'
```

now reads

```
perf.js
1087:    Benchmark.Suite('`_.includes` searching an array')
1092:        _.includes(numbers, limit - 1)'
1097:    Benchmark.Suite('`_.includes` searching an object')
1102:        _.includes(object, limit - 1)'
1106:  if (lodash.includes('ab', 'ab') && _.includes('ab', 'ab')) {
1108:      Benchmark.Suite('`_.includes` searching a string')
1113:          _.includes(strNumbers, "," + (limit - 1))'
```

title: Add `_.lowerCase`, `_.lowerFirst`, `_.toLower`, `_.toUpper`, `_.upperCase`, `_.upperFirst` tests
body: Ref. https://github.com/lodash/lodash/issues/1534.

title: jQuery Dev Summit ‚Äô15 Items
body:
- [x] Add `_.lowerCase`, `_.lowerFirst`, `_.toLower`, `_.toUpper`, `_.upperCase`, `_.upperFirst` tests
- [x] Add [lodash-fp](https://github.com/lodash/lodash-fp) `convert` module to lodash as `fp`
- [ ] Break [lodash-cli](https://github.com/lodash/lodash-cli) bin/lodash into multiple modules
- [ ] Contribute to the [lodash website](https://github.com/lodash/lodash.github.io/issues/8)
- [ ] Add `foo.default.js` modules for the [lodash-es](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/tree/es) build.
- [ ] Sanity check lodash [perf](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/tree/master/perf) compared to v3
- [ ] Blog drafts/outlines for lodash v4
- [ ] Outstanding [docdown issues](https://github.com/jdalton/docdown/issues)
- [ ] Outstanding [lodash-fp issues](https://github.com/lodash/lodash-fp/issues)

title: A _.del counterpart to _.get and _.set
body:
Hi.

I'm using `_.get` and `_.set` for configuration objects but I'm missing a delete functionality that actually uses the delete statement to remove a key from an object (I guess a `.splice` from an array? or just a `_.without`?). Right now I'm using `_.set(k, undefined);` but that's a pretty bad solution, right?

title: jscs@2.3.1 untested ‚ö†Ô∏è
body:
Hello :wave: :warning::warning::warning: jscs just published its new version 2.3.1, which **is covered by your current version range**. After updating it in your project **an automated test run couldn‚Äôt be detected** within five minutes. This means it‚Äôs now **unclear whether your software still works**. Manually check if that‚Äôs still the case and close this pull request ‚Äì if it broke, use this branch to work on adaptions and fixes. Do you think getting a pull request for every single new version of your dependencies is too noisy? Configure continuous integration and you will only receive them when tests fail.¬† Happy fixing and merging :palm_tree: --- [GitHub Release](https://github.com/jscs-dev/node-jscs/releases/tag/v2.3.1)

Version 2.3.1 (10-14-2015):

A bunch of bug fixes in this release!

The Future

We are probably going to start 3.0 for the next release (mainly integrating CST into JSCS). If you want to know more about CST check out the previous changelog.

Our current plan is to move our 3.0/cst branch to master and then create a 2.x branch to continue to release bug fixes / contributer PRs. The core team will be mainly focused on tackling issues on our 3.0 roadmap (which we are still planning). We would love to hear your feedback on what you think should be in 3.0 and beyond!

Bug Fixes:

  • disallowMultipleVarDecl - improve {"allExcept": ["require"]} logic (ValYouW)
// Allow MemberExpressions: require('a').b.c;
var fs = require('fs');
var Emitter = require('events').EventEmitter;
  • disallowSpaceAfterObjectKeys - Allow no space after key with align option. (Andrey Ermakov)
// this should be allowed
var f = {
    "name": 1,
    "x": 2
};
  • disallowUnusedParams - correctly output unused param name (Oleg Gaidarenko)
// Should output:
// Param unusedParam is not used at input
var a = function(unusedParam) {}
  • requireDollarBeforejQueryAssignment - validate all keys (Brian Dixon)
// check all keys
var x = {
  bar: 1,
  foo: $(".foo") // error here
};
  • requireDollarBeforejQueryAssignment - Ignore array destructuring (Simen Bekkhus)
// Don't error with this
const [beep, boop] = meep;
var $s = $("#id")
  • CLI - "auto-configure" argument should always be at the end (Oleg Gaidarenko)
// correct autoconfigure args
jscs --autoconfigure ./files/here
  • js-file - make parser not confuse token types (Oleg Gaidarenko)
// Fixes issues with keywords like with
class A {
  catch() {}
}

Again, a big thanks to everything using JSCS! Definitely continue to report any bugs and new ideas! We always appreciate any help/PRs!

We'll probably be moving more of the new rule/option issues to orphaned which just means that they are on hold but anyone can still PR it or reopen it later. Remember to tweet at us at @jscs_dev and chat with us on our gitter room!

@hzoo

title: Expected behaviour of _.has({ test: 1}, 'test.'), true or false?
body:
Which of the following is correct?
1. `_.has({ test: 1}, 'test.') // true`
2. `_.has({ test: 1}, 'test.') // false`

I could not find a test or a previous issue about this, sorry if there's one.

If it's 1 so what about adding an example to the docs specifying this edge case? 
I am happy to help with a PR either way (docs or code), what do you think?

title: _.sortBy([...], 'string', this); does not work in 3.10.1
body:
```
_.sortBy(['a', 'ccc', 'bb'], 'length');
=> ["a", "bb", "ccc"]
```

Adding `this` as the third argument made `sortBy` function did nothing at all.

```
_.sortBy(['a', 'ccc', 'bb'], 'length', this);
=> ["a", "ccc", "bb"]
```

However, I was using version 2.4.1 and both mentioned statements worked perfectly.

Note that the later statement appears in _Backbone.js_ inside `Collection.sort()` so that's the reason why I can't simply remove the third argument myself.

title: index.js -> lodash.js
body:
Hi there.

In my project, for some reasons, I have to put lodash var to window (I cannot use require() for dependence management).

jQuery, React, Backbone and many other js libraries has dist file named as library itself.
`backbone.js`
`dist/jquery.js`
etc.

But for lodash I have to use `gulp-rename` to copy `index.js` to `lodash.js`.

Why main file is named `index.js` ?

For defining main file there is an package.json option
`"main": "lodash.js"`

title: _.capitalize() doesn't format uppercase strings.
body:
It may be intentional functionality, but `_.capitalize()` only formats lowercase strings and not uppercase strings. 

Example:
 `_.capitalize('UPPERCASE') => 'UPPERCASE'` (current)
`_.capitalize('UPPERCASE') => 'Uppercase'` (desired)

title: Rename `_.restParam` to `_.rest`?
body:
I figured I'd bring up renaming `_.restParam` to `_.rest` in v4.0.
This would mean the existing `_.rest` would be renamed `_.tail` and I'd either drop `_.first` for `_.head` or make it an alias of `_.head`.

Thoughts?

title: it seems that _.pluck is not defined in 3.10.1
Allow _.where and similar functions to match on an array of values
Add isGeneratorFunction(fn)
body:
Looks like there's a bunch of ways to check if a function is also a generator function...
http://stackoverflow.com/questions/16754956/check-if-function-is-a-generator

Could lodash decide on the most bulletproof approach and implement it?

title: _.forEach() returns Object when called on Array
body:
This is true:

``` Javascript
typeof _.forEach([1,2,3], function () {}) === 'object'
```

Documentation on `_.forEach` states:

> _Returns
> (Array|Object|string): Returns collection_

So I thought it would return an Array if called on an Array?

title: _.every and _.some short-circuit evaluation
body:
It is not clear if the `_.every` function always iterates all the
collection or if it stops at the first falsy value; the `_.some` function
documents this feature, and that creates even more confusion. 

I documented the `_.every` function in this sense. I also have updated 
the tests for `_.some` and `_.every` to evidence this feature.

title: Add `thisArg` to `_.defer`?

Is there a reason this shouldn't exist?

title: _.assign not working as expected, when sources are created using prototype
lodash templates and template strings
body:
I'm trying to use es6 template strings in my templates in Yeoman, but there seems to be an error when trying to use them.

I singled out this example in lodash 3.10.1

``` js
var compiled = _.template('var test = `${hello} <%= user %>`;');
console.log(compiled({user: 'test'}));
```

I get the following error

```
ReferenceError: hello is not defined
```

I would expect the output to be 

``` js
var test = `${hello} test`;
```

any idea how to fix this?

thanks :)

title: Minification failing when using Microsoft's System.Web.Optimization (the default minification provider)
body:
I'm hesitant to open this issue as it's probably an issue with System.Web.Optimization, but anyway just letting you know since 3.7.0 minification has been failing with System.Web.Optimization which is asp.net's default bundling/minification provider.   

I've lodged an issue on their code repository but It's not very active.
https://aspnetoptimization.codeplex.com/workitem/169

Below is the response you get from my asp.net mvc project.
https://gist.github.com/ichpuchtli/4383a95f1912fcd92067  

If you look at the top of the response copied below, the minifier reports an error which it prepends to the response. 

``` js
/* Minification failed. Returning unminified contents.
(19,462-469): run-time error JS1019: Can't have 'break' outside of loop: break n
 */
/**
 * @license
 * lodash 3.7.0 (Custom Build) lodash.com/license | Underscore.js 1.8.3 underscorejs.org/LICENSE
 * Build: `lodash modern -o ./lodash.js`
 */
...
```

The line number 19 does not map to your source as it was partially minified even though it said it returned the unminified contents.

I will update this issue with news from their codeplex site. 

Regards,
Sam

title: Minified build for Node Modules
body:
Hey there. First of all, congrats on `0` open issues over `1170+` closed - that's impressive. :)

I'm very aware that there's a ton of customization options for building minified / broken up versions of `lodash` for use in browsers. I am also aware the NPM module size is not _usually_ considered a concern.

With those points in mind, let me bring up my consideration:

I've been working a few CLI apps in node, which means a human being (developer) is going to download them and use them as tools. In this case, when the user types `npm install mycliapp`, he is staring at the screen, waiting for every KB to download. Optimally, I want these applications as small as possible.

The full `lodash` you get with an `npm install lodash` is huge - `822kb`. This compares to the `50k` full minified version. In an attempt to solve this, I turned to the individual builds (`lodash-isobject`, etc.). By the time I pulled in the 12 `lodash` modules that my project used, the size exceeded `822kb`, due to the added on luggage of licenses, readmes, duplicate dependencies, etc.

This seems like an unnecessary problem.

I thought of building my own minified version and publishing it to NPM, but I know I'm not going to maintain it as much as we both would like, and you don't seem to like that idea either:

https://github.com/ide/ld-min/issues/1

Is there any way you could guys could add on to all of your awesome build automation the publishing of an official `lodash-min` Node module?

That'd be totally awesome, and given the popularity of `lodash`, you'd probably save terabits of web bandwidth over time :)

title: Deactivate all delimiters for _template() ?
body:
With the use of gulp-template, I have something like this :

``` javascript
 gulp.src(['/_projects/'+ SITE_PARAM.name+'/**'])
    .pipe(template({ 
          'CLIENT_NAME' : SITE_PARAM.client,
          'PROJECT_NAME' : SITE_PARAM.projectname
      }, {'interpolate' : /__CRI-([\s\S]+?)-CRI__/g}))
    .on('error', console.error.bind(console))
    .pipe(gulp.dest('/_projects/'+ SITE_PARAM.name))
}
```

I used custom delimiters cause the templates parsed have already ES6 delimiters. In fact, parsed files also have code like : 

``` csharp
<%@ Application Codebehind="Global.asax.cs" Inherits="Cri.__CRI-CLIENT_NAME-CRI__.__CRI-PROJECT_NAME-CRI__.Web.MvcApplication" Language="C#" %>
```

This causing me an errors :

```
{ [SyntaxError: Unexpected token ILLEGAL]
  source: 'function(obj) {\nobj || (obj = {});\nvar __t, __p = \'\', __e = _.escape, __j = Array.protot
odebehind="Global.asax.cs" Inherits="Cri.__CRI-CLIENT_NAME-CRI__.__CRI-PROJECT_NAME-CRI__.Web.MvcApplic
  name: 'SyntaxError',
  message: 'Unexpected token ILLEGAL',
  stack: 'SyntaxError: Unexpected token ILLEGAL\n    at Function (native)\n    at template (C:\\Users\\
modules\\lodash\\dist\\lodash.js:6306:22)\n    at DestroyableTransform._transform (C:\\Users\\rene.domi
)\n    at DestroyableTransform.Transform._read (C:\\Users\\rene.domingue\\AppData\\Roaming\\npm\\node_m
ream\\lib\\_stream_transform.js:184:10)\n    at DestroyableTransform.Transform._write (C:\\Users\\rene.
es\\through2\\node_modules\\readable-stream\\lib\\_stream_transform.js:172:12)\n    at doWrite (C:\\Use
ode_modules\\through2\\node_modules\\readable-stream\\lib\\_stream_writable.js:237:10)\n    at writeOrB
lp-template\\node_modules\\through2\\node_modules\\readable-stream\\lib\\_stream_writable.js:227:5)\n
odules\\slush-cri\\node_modules\\gulp-template\\node_modules\\through2\\node_modules\\readable-stream\\
node_modules\\slush-cri\\node_modules\\gulp\\node_modules\\vinyl-fs\\node_modules\\through2\\node_modul
Data\\Roaming\\npm\\node_modules\\slush-cri\\node_modules\\gulp\\node_modules\\vinyl-fs\\node_modules\\
  fileName: 'C:\\_projects\\test-test\\SiteConcoursTemplate\\__CRI-CLIENT_NAME-CRI__-__CRI-PROJECT_NAME
  showStack: false,
  showProperties: true,
  plugin: 'gulp-template' }
```

If I remove the "<%" and "%>" it's working just fine.
There is a way I can disable the parse of  "<%" and "%>" delimiters ?

``` js
Number.isInteger(0.1);     // false

Number.isInteger(-100000); // true
Number.isInteger(NaN);     // false
Number.isInteger(0);       // true
Number.isInteger("10");    // false
```

Please tell me if that's acceptable.

title: lodash deepclone scales poorly
body:
I encountered this in particular in cloning huge cross linked tree structures for npm.

Per discussion on Twitter, this is due to the circular dependency check:

```
 * @param {Array} [stackA=[]] Tracks traversed source objects.
 * @param {Array} [stackB=[]] Associates clones with source counterparts.
```

```
  var length = stackA.length;
  while (length--) {
    if (stackA[length] == value) {
      return stackB[length];
    }
  }
```

Now, if lodash could count on access to Maps or WeakMaps then this could be easily worked with of course.  This led me to investigating how es6 map shims work‚Äì many of them work like lodash, doing a linear scan of a keys array, but core-js does not:

https://github.com/zloirock/core-js

It's implementation is here:

https://github.com/zloirock/core-js/blob/master/modules/es6.map.js

Which in turn has the bulk of its implementation here:

https://github.com/zloirock/core-js/blob/master/modules/%24.collection-strong.js

If you dig into that, you can see that ultimately they add a non-enumerable element named `ID` with a unique id they generate and use that as the key for their Map objects.

Uh... I'm not exactly sure what I'm suggesting here. The current behavior works fine for small objects but goes very very bad with large ones. At the same time, mutating the original object is super ugly. =/ I kind of don't like either option.

My colleague @zkat suggested maybe having deep-clone take an optional additional argument that's a function that, given an object returns a unique identifier for it.  If this was passed in then deep-clone could use this to compute a key to be used in a fast property lookup instead of scanning a list‚Äì with the list scan as a fallback if such a function doesn't exist. The end user could then choose to either mutate their objects or use knowledge of how their data structures to select an already existing unique property‚Ä¶

title: _.trimLeft() removes extra char
body: http://plnkr.co/edit/bNzB2lQE0yVUG45euTvK?p=preview

title: sliceAt which returns the opposite of slice
body: If I slice a section of an array, I get that array, but it seems like it could be handy to get the balance of the array that's being thrown away. So if I have an array with elements [1..100] and I want elements [1..50, 60..100], I'd like to be able to grab that without doing a couple steps to slice each side and concatenate them. Is there a function like this? It seems like there's a few functions which return the removed elements (`_.remove`, `_.pull`) and none which do what I'm looking for. There is `_.reject`, but I'd rather not have to iterate through the array if I know the range of indexes to remove. In the `_.remove` issue discussion, [someone suggested this](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/issues/281#issuecomment-18384938) for `_.pull` and someone pointed to `_.without`, but without is a fair bit broader since it removes matching values.

title: lodash + jshint + Komodo Edit issue
body:
jshint, as of 2.7.0, have moved from using underscore to using lodash. They have done a straight swap out of libraries. I am using Komodo Edit which can use jshint in its editor. With jshint 2.6.3 and Komodo, I have no issues but as soon as I move to 2.7.0+ then it no longer functions. I replaced lodash in jshint 2.8.0 with the latest underscore 1.8.3 and everything works again. The problem seems to be with detecting the context in runInContext. I don't know who owns the fault, is it Komodo, jshint or lodash? I have opened issues with the other projects in the hope that a future solution can be found (other than me copying and pasting in underscore as a replacement of lodash). 
https://github.com/jshint/jshint/issues/2696
https://github.com/Komodo/KomodoEdit/issues/603

title: feature: function for boolean pattern-matching
_.sortByOrder with null values
body:
Lodash  3.10.1
Trying to sort objects with null value

``` javascript
var users = [
  { 'user': 'fred',   'age': 48 },
  { 'user': 'barney', 'age': 34 },
  { 'user': 'fred',   'age': null },
  { 'user': 'barney', 'age': 36 }
];

_.pluck(_.sortByOrder(users, ['age', 'user'], ['desc', 'desc']), "age");
```

and result is:

``` javascript
[null, 48, 36, 34]
```

expected to be like:

``` javascript
[48, 36, 34, null]
```

or i'm wrong?
Thanks.

**Update:**
seems like it's related to _.sortBy realisation, look the following examples for the same array:
- Lodash 3.10.1:

``` javascript
_.pluck(_.sortBy(users, 'age'), "age");
// [34, 36, 48, null]
```
- Lodash 3.6.0:

``` javascript
_.pluck(_.sortBy(users, 'age'), "age");
// [null, 34, 36, 48]
```

title: Something wrong with 'reverse' in chain
body:
Use `lodash@3.10.1`.

Try to run this chain in node ‚Äì>

``` js
_([[1], [undefined], [3]])
    .take(2)
    .map(_.compact)
    .reverse()
    .value() // ‚Äì> [ [ 3 ], [] ] ‚Äì wrong!
```

Try to run this chain in browser ‚Äì>

``` js
_([[1], [undefined], [3]])
    .take(2)
    .map(_.compact)
    .reverse()
    .value() // ‚Äì> [ [], [ 1 ]] ‚Äì OK!
```

title: Decapitalize?
body:
Heya,

I had a scenario where I wanted to decapitalize a string, i.e. "FOO" => "fOO" and noted that only a `capitalize` method existed in lodash.

Is that something that'd be of interest for core to provide parity, or not widely used enough?

title: Passing 3 or more lists to _.zipWith doesn't make any sense
body:
It looks like the iteratee function is being invoked for each pair(?) of elements:

```
_.zipWith([10,20,30],[40,50,60],[70,80,90], function() { console.log(Array.prototype.slice.call(arguments)); return -1; })
[ 10, 40, 1, [ 10, 40, 70 ] ]
[ -1, 70, 2, [ 10, 40, 70 ] ]
[ 20, 50, 1, [ 20, 50, 80 ] ]
[ -1, 80, 2, [ 20, 50, 80 ] ]
[ 30, 60, 1, [ 30, 60, 90 ] ]
[ -1, 90, 2, [ 30, 60, 90 ] ]
[ -1, -1, -1 ]
```

According to the documentation the callback should be invoked with "(accumulator, value, index, group)", but you can see the accumulator only comes back on every other invocation.  And the index bounces between 1 and 2, which seems wrong.

My expectation is that the `zipWith` iteratee function would be invoked with one argument from each list, and nothing more.  (You can make a case to maybe add an index at the end).  So I'd expect to see something more like:

```
_.zipWith([10,20,30],[40,50,60],[70,80,90], function() { console.log(Array.prototype.slice.call(arguments)); return -1; })
[ 10, 40, 70]
[ 20, 50, 80]
[ 30, 60, 90]
```

I think the `_.add` example in the doc is a bit too forgiving.  Something with string concatenation would probably be a better example and test.  E.g., this is what I get from lodash 3.9.1:

```
lodash.zipWith(['a','b','c'],['x','y','z'],['1','2','3'], function(a1, a2, a3) { return a1 + a2 + a3; })
[ 'ax112', 'by122', 'cz132' ]
```

which does not, AFAICT, make any sense.

But maybe I'm misreading what/how zipWith is supposed to work and the current semantics make sense, but then the documentation needs a lot of work.

title: v3.10.1: Arguments mixup when combining _.find and _.partialRight

body:
When running the following code: 

```
var before = [0, 1, 2];
var after = _.sortBy(before, function(x) { return NaN; });
```

`after` will be `[2, 1, 0]` which is a bit unexpected given that `sortBy()` should be stable. This behavior has changed at least since lodash version 2.4.1.

(A jsfiddle is here: https://jsfiddle.net/yacu5x49/1/)

title: How does _.difference work?
body:
Hi,

I have just created a little jsfiddle that shows how I would expect _.difference works. The lodash version in jsfiddle is _2.2.1_. https://jsfiddle.net/97bdb7ak/

The two arrays are 

["55fa3e2d9268d7127b6a2ad6","55f608920c7a8baf417a68eb","55f6053a0c7a8baf417a68e1","55fa3dfa9268d7127b6a2ad4","55f6083b0c7a8baf417a68e9","55f605800c7a8baf417a68e3","55f5f53b0c7a8baf417a68dd",**"55f62b020c7a8baf417a68f1"**]

["55fa3e2d9268d7127b6a2ad6","55f608920c7a8baf417a68eb","55f6053a0c7a8baf417a68e1","55fa3dfa9268d7127b6a2ad4","55f6083b0c7a8baf417a68e9","55f605800c7a8baf417a68e3","55f5f53b0c7a8baf417a68dd"]

However, in my node application I am using _lodash 3.10.0_ and the output for the same invocation is

> > added 55fa3e2d9268d7127b6a2ad6
> > added 55f608920c7a8baf417a68eb
> > added 55f6053a0c7a8baf417a68e1
> > added 55fa3dfa9268d7127b6a2ad4
> > added 55f6083b0c7a8baf417a68e9
> > added 55f605800c7a8baf417a68e3
> > added 55f5f53b0c7a8baf417a68dd
> > **>> added 55f62b020c7a8baf417a68f1**
> > added 55f607870c7a8baf417a68e7

Actually, it should only contain the one I marked bold, right?

title: About _.has
body:
```
console.log(
    _.has(req.kms,"redis"),
    _.has(req.kms,"redis.comment_rule"),
    req.kms.redis.comment_rule.length
)
```

output
true false 1

why?

title: [idea] modular architecture
body:
It'd be nice if all the functions were requireable/importable without having to import the entire library. f.e.:

``` js
import isEqual from 'lodash/isEqual'
```

We'd get the library by installing with NPM. Doing

```
import _ from 'lodash'
```

would import everything, like normal. With the use of static analyzers and ES6, we could do

``` js
import { isEqual, after } as _ from 'lodash'
```

to import selective things.

For this to work properly, each function would have to be stored in it's own file and `import` whatever it needs (or `require` if you prefer CommonJS). There'd be an index.js file which would import everything and export everything, and that what you'd get when you `import _ from 'lodash'`.

title: Map Parses Long Arrays Incorrectly
"where" for object
body:
I have found that I quite frequently need to filter a single object against a set of properties. Basically same as `_.where` for lists, but for a single object.

Example:

```
return (obj && obj.name == 'Bob' && obj.age == '42') ? obj : undefined;
```

Using `_.isMatch` I can make it slightly more compact:

```
return (_.isMatch(obj, {name: 'Bob', age: 42}) ? obj : undefined;
```

Sure, there's not a huge amount of characters to be saved, but it would be more compact and elegant if there was a dedicated function with the same semantics as `_.where`, basically performing the same test as `_.isMatch` but returning the object instead of true in case of a match:

```
return _.match(obj, {name: 'Bob', age:42});
```

Is there such a function already that I'm missing? If not, would it be considerable to accept contribution of one?

Typical usecase: `where` is useful e.g. when retrieving a collection of objects from a database and where you for some reason need to perform additional filtering in code. A `match` function would serve the same purpose for cases where a single object is retrieved, in a very clean and compact way.

title: Add flush to debounce/throttle cancel.
body:
I would like to request the addition of a flush mechanism on the `cancel` function for debounced/throttled functions.  i.e. if the first argument is true-ish and there is a pending call fire the pending call immediately and then cancel all timers.

I have a situation where I am cancelling pending debouncers in a destructor but I still want the last pending state update to synchronise, which I am having to do manually.  It would be nice to be able to flush that last state change automatically when I cancel the debouncer.

title: Possibly support chaining returning a function
body:
Currently, to force a chain to evaluation (as opposed to implicitly ending it with certain chain functions) you have to call .value(). Is there any merit to making the chain object a function, with the same fields and behavior as current, to allow you to end the chain by directly calling the return? From the given example for _(value) :

```
_.isArray(squares.value());
```

to

```
_.isArray(squares());
```

It would take slightly more memory, but the speed would be unchanged (except for ending the chain which would actually be faster as no dereferencing of the method).

title: allow .filter to return the unfiltered
feature: _.find should work on functions
body:
``` coffee
let foo = { a:1 }
_.find(foo, a => a == 1) // 1

let bar = () => null
bar.a = 1
_.find(bar, a => a == 1) // undefined

let bar = () => null
bar.a = 1
_.find(_.values(bar), a => a == 1) // 1
```

Using sailsjs 0.11, node 4.0, and curlrequest latest. Does it have anything to do with copying from windows to linux or linux to windows git showed some warning regarding modes or mods. Does this looks familiar works awesome locally while bloating with error on heroku.

title: trim, trimLeft, trimRight allow regex
body:
It would be useful if trim functions allowed regex in addition to list of characters, e.g.

``` js
_.trimRight('foo<a><b><c>', /\<[a-z]\>$/);
> foo
```

title: String functions do not work as expected when subject includes astral symbols or ANSI escape codes
body:
`padRight` does not pad the string that has ANSI escape codes, e.g.

``` js
_.padRight("\u001b[31mfoo\u001b[39m\u001b[34mbar\u001b[39mbaz", 10, 'X');
```

The same issue applies to all string functions.

The reason this is happening is primarily because the `length` property of the value is affected by ANSI escape codes. `padRight` should only be concerned with visible characters.

Consider using [`string-length`](https://github.com/sindresorhus/string-length) by @sindresorhus.

title: Add string splice function

``` json
"lodash": "^2.4.1"
```

title: Fully applied function
body:
What are your thoughts on having a fully applied function helper.

I see this pattern where a callback needs to be called with a certain parameter which means I can't use it directly, and I have to wrap it with an anonymous function.

i.e.

``` javascript
var bar = 'baz';
doPromise.then(function() { foo(bar); });
```

It could instead be written as:

``` javascript
var bar = 'baz';
doPromise.then(_.fullyApplied(foo, bar));
```

Maybe this already exists and I missed it.

What do you think?

title: question: lodash-y getOrDefault()

body: I see it exists in `lodash-contrib` but didn't see any other tickets here asking for it. I find myself wanting it quite often, could open a ticket to add if it'd be considered.
